# Scale: Major in G# (Mode: Phrygian, Shape: D)

The Major scale in G# (also known as Ab) is a scale consisting of the following notes: G#, A#, B#, C#, D#, E#, and F##. In the Phrygian mode, this scale starts on the third scale degree, which in this case is B#.

## Notes and Intervals:

- G# (Tonic)
- A# (Major 2nd from G#)
- B# (Minor 3rd from G#)
- C# (Perfect 4th from G#)
- D# (Perfect 5th from G#)
- E# (Major 6th from G#)
- F## (Major 7th from G#)

## Genre and Musical Flavor:

The Major scale in G# (Phrygian mode) is not commonly used due to the complexity of the notes, especially with the abundance of sharps. However, it can provide a unique and exotic sound when employed effectively. The Phrygian mode in a Major scale can evoke feelings of tension and mystery due to its distinctive intervals.
